fields.physical_description:
English; early 18th century.

Rectangular, supported on a plinth with four short pad feet. Two short and two long drawers, with oak linings, the drawer-fronts veneered with walnut and herring-bone borders. Original brass key-plate escutcheons and pendant ring-handles. Lifting-handles at sides. Both sides and back veneered. The top is veneered with figured walnut with herring-bone and cross-cut borders. It is divided into two laterally and opens to form a desk-top - lined with modern velvet. The whole top is hinged at the front and can be raised to provide an adjustable reading-slope, There is a shallow drawer at each end under the hinged top.
fields.dimensions: Height: 76.2 cm, Width: 74.9 cm, Depth: 64.8 cm
fields.public_access_description: On loan to Red House Museum.
fields.bibliography: A similar chest with five instead of three drawers is illustrated in: R. W. Symonds, <u>'Veneered Walnut Furniture</u><u>'</u>, fig.16
fields.credit: Gift of Brigadier W. E. Clark CMG, DSO through The Art Fund
fields.history_note:
Dresser, gift of Brigadier W E Clark on 25 May 1960

Notes from R.P. 603593 & 50/517

Gift form
Lists as "Chest of drawers - walnut veneer on oak with adjustable top.  English; early 18th century".

3/11/60 minute, Hayward to Molesworth
reports on inspection of Clark's gift and describes "A walnut bachelor's chest of about 1700 with adjustable folding top for writing on cabriole legs.  This is a rare and important piece and is far more important than the one we have at present on view".

2/11/60 letter, Clark
describes the chest as "an early 18th century walnut bachelors chest on short legs with (sp….) feet …..about 30 inches by 12 - It has a double flap top which opens into a writing flap".
